comments.author: mx12.levins
comments.body: I don't have many new images of this artwork, but it has been exhibited in London twice, as well as in Miami and Manchester. Despite this, I managed to find a couple of images. The inspiration for this piece came from a real skull I had in front of me, blending it with my emotions at the time while sketching it in a clinic.Another noteworthy aspect of this artwork is its significant size and the presence created by the acrylic glass and shadow gap. The oak frame complements it perfectly. Additionally, I drew inspiration from one of my earliest art collectors, who once expressed disbelief that this artwork was still available. I look forward to reconnecting with him soon! 11:11

comments.author: mx12.levins
comments.body: Hey guys, the time is coming to share my story behind everything. People are starting to ask about it across various media platforms, wondering about my story and its origins. But the fight began back in 2015, that year, I fell into a coma, and it took a long time to recover - to speak, move around, and so on. Even as I opened my eyes, surrounded by many crying faces, I couldn't understand why they were crying. After weeks of pain, I gradually regained consciousness, but I still couldn't communicate properly. Instead, I tried to sketch out my feelings and needs, rough as they were, and people understood. That's when I realized the power of my art - a universal language like Bitcoin, usable worldwide.There's much more to tell, even after nine years, I can't shake off these memories. Little things still happen, like removing shards of glass from my body - the last two were taken out from my mouth, causing pain whenever I ate. This is my reality.Regarding this artwork, the bureaucratic struggle began swiftly. The person who drove over me while under the influence of drugs and alcohol also had good insurance, but they didn't want to pay up. They offered me a small settlement, threatening long legal battles if I refused. Out of this struggle emerged art, reflecting my experiences - leaving home, frozen accounts, and more. The fight continues, and I began sketching this artwork in the clinic. The doctor even gave me a model skull to sketch, a reminder of what happened to me. Despite my efforts, I often forget what happened yesterday, undergoing daily training for years to be where I am now. Art has become a part of me, without it, I fear losing myself.That's why I turned to Bitcoin art - it's my lifeline. If there are no lovers or collectors of my Bitcoin art, I may disappear one day, unable to survive, draw, or remember. It's a scary thought, every day, I fear forgetting everything. I even considered creating comics to tell my story and preserve it, perhaps opening a crowdfunding campaign to make it happen before it's too late.As for this artwork, it will be a historical record of who I am, showcasing why we must fight for financial freedom, care about privacy, and embrace Bitcoin. Through my experiences, I hope others can learn and understand.There isn't much information available about my story, perhaps you can find some fragments here and there, but there's no comprehensive account of what lies behind this artist. However, from time to time, I do share some insights and comments. I'm considering creating a thread behind the scenes and this will be the very first place where people can find the story. Perhaps you, my friends, have better ideas on how and where to share it. Just let me know. Thank you, everyone!
